I recently found this excellent resource.
 
 Hemant Mehta, in Human Migration: A Brief History, has reported on a nice Flash presentation of humanity's Paleolithic migrations: Journey of Mankind: Peopling of the World.
 
 It focused on our present human species, mentioning the Neanderthals, Homo erectus, and H. floresiensis only peripherally; it would have been nice for the map to show their distribution also.
 
 But that aside, it had lots of helpful additional information that one can get by pressing appropriate buttons in the map, like explaining ice ages, the Toba volcano, living on seashores, the mitochondrial Eve and Y-chromosome Adam, etc.
 
 It is an animated map that shows the lines of migration growing from one step to another; you press a button to go to the next step.
 
 The steps:
 
 160 kya - Homo sapiens originates in east Africa; the map's position is little north of Lake Victoria
 
 135 kya - humanity reaches eastern and southern Africa; time of the Herto fossils (H. s. idaltu).
 
 115 kya - Interglacial; Africa was relatively wet, allowing humanity to spread to the Levant, the eastern Mediterranean coast from the Sinai Peninsula to Anatolia/Turkey.
 
 90 kya - Those Levantines died out as a result of a global cold snap that turned the Levant and north Africa into extreme desert. Neanderthals later moved in.
 
 85 kya - the ancestors of all non-Africans crossed the Gates of Grief strait at the southern end of the Red Sea.
 
 75 kya - these people spread along the south Asian coast, reaching south China.
 
 74 kya - In Indonesia, Mt. Toba erupts, complete with a sound effect . It creates a 6-year "volcanic winter" followed by a 1000-year cold snap. Humanity suffers a population crash to about 10,000 individuals, and dies out between Iran and Indonesia.
 
 65 kya - Humanity repopulates the southeastern-Asian coastline, and spreads into New Guinea and northern Australia.
 
 52 kya - The climate warmed, and humanity spread further into Australia, the coastline of India, and into the Fertile Crescent, finally returning to the Levant.
 
 45 kya - A mini Ice Age followed by some short warm periods; the Cro-Magnon people spread over Europe.
 
 40 kya - Humanity spreads into Spain, north Africa, and central and eastern Asia.
 
 25 kya - Cold period. Humanity spreads into northern and northeastern Asia.
 
 22 kya - Humanity reaches North America, crossing the then-high-and-dry land of Beringia and making it through the Canadian-Rockies ice-less corridor.
 
 19 kya - Big Ice Age; northern Eurasia and North America were largely depopulated except for a few refuge areas.
 
 15 kya - The Last Glacial Maximum. Humanity makes it into South America.
 
 12.5 kya - The glaciers start to retreat and the climate becomes moister. Humanity has now spread over much of North American and all of South America.
 
 10 kya - As the glaciers continue to repeat, humanity continues to repopulate northern North America.
 
 8 kya - Humanity spreads further in north Africa, repopulates north Asia, and enters the British Isles and Scandinavia. Agriculture invented in several places: the Levant, south China, New Guinea, Mexico, and the lower Amazon River.
 
 Overall, it misses a few small cultures that advanced in places that are not shown, but it shows the major migrations, etc.

 Rebecca L. Cann
 
 Ongoing debate about proper interpretation of DNA sequence polymorphisms and their ability to reconstruct human population history illustrates a important change in perspective that we have achieved in the past 20 years of population genetics. To what extent does the history of a locus represent the history of a population? Tools originally developed for molecular systematics, where genetic lineages have been separated by speciation events, are routinely applied to the analysis of variation within our species, with conflicting results. Because of automated technologies and linkage analysis, we are poised to harvest a wealth of information about our past, if we are successful in moving beyond a current polarization regarding models of human evolution. Generally, American pedants (mostly my high school English teachers) seem to take glee in pointing out how incorrect it is to end a sentence with a preposition. However, none of them, to my knowledge, studied or spoke another language, earned a degree in linguistics, or met Winston Churchill. I have studied three languages and speak two (nobody speaks Latin) and have a degree in linguistics. I only know stories about Sir Winston. One story goes like this: It seems that Sir Winston wrote own speeches by listing the points he wished to make. He gave this list to his speech writer who produced a draft. Sir Winston then read the draft and made notes and corrections and returned it to the speech writer. The process continued until the speech was what Sir Winston desired. It seems that on one occasion the speech writer corrected a phrase from Sir Winston and made the note that one should not end a sentence with a preposition. Sir Winston put back his original words and added the note, "This is the type of errant pedantry up with which I shall not put."
 
 Sir Winston's point was that in English, certain verbs, by concept, include what seems to be a preposition. In fact, almost universally across other languages, ideas expressed by these peculiar verb+preposition combinations are a single, unique verb. For example, "to put up with" in Spanish is the verb "tolerar", that has no relation to the verb "to put" - "poner". In Spanish, there is a different verb "to look for" (buscar) than "to look at" (mirar).
 
 However, in this case, Foxtuba is 100% correct. Neither the verb "to be" nor the verb "to evolve", in any language, has a linguistic concept that includes a preposition. Thus, "to be at" and "to evolve from" are both incorrect as the end of a sentence.
 
 As we used to say back when I studied linguistics, "Never use a preposition to end a sentence with." - except when it is conceptually part of the verb.
